name: Channel Degradation / Incision
functionStatement: Balanced sediment supply and transport preserves bed elevations, substrate sizes, spawning/benthic habitats, and supports riparian succession.
descriptionMarkdown: Bed is stable, with no active incision disconnecting floodplain unless minor incision is normal.
howToMeasureMarkdown: Extract cross sections from LiDAR or survey data to compare bed elevation to the floodplain and locate active headcuts.

levels.label: Good
levels.criteriaMarkdown: Good: No active downcutting. Bed elevation is stable. (Suggested index range 0.70-1.0)

levels.label: Fair
levels.criteriaMarkdown: Fair: Minor localized incision. / Noticeable incision or one or two moderate headcuts that reduce floodplain access. (Suggested index range 0.40-0.69)

levels.label: Poor
levels.criteriaMarkdown: Poor: Severe channel-wide incision with multiple major headcuts. (Suggested index range 0.0-0.39)

levels.label: Strongly Disagree
levels.criteriaMarkdown:
Observation: Multiple large active headcuts. Floodplain largely disconnected.
Criteria: ER < 1.4 reach-wide. Widespread incision (Schumm et al., 1984; Rosgen 2006).

levels.label: Disagree
levels.criteriaMarkdown:
Observation: High banks and lowered bed. One to two moderate headcuts migrating.
Criteria: ER < 1.4. Observable upstream migration of headcuts (Simon & Rinaldi 2006).

levels.label: Agree
levels.criteriaMarkdown:
Observation: Localized bed lowering. One small headcut with vegetation establishing.
Criteria: ER ~1.4-2.2. Limited headcut activity (Rosgen 1996, 2006).

levels.label: Strongly Agree
levels.criteriaMarkdown:
Observation: Low banks with inset benches. No active headcuts observed.
Criteria: ER > 2.2. No active headcuts (Rosgen 1996, 2006).

references: USGS 3DEP LiDAR cross sections and hillshade
